item.title: By: Wayne
item.dc:creator: Wayne
item.description:
Colossians 2:16–17 (NAS) 16 Therefore no one is to act as your judge in regard to food or drink or in respect to a festival or a new moon or a Sabbath day— 17 things which are a mere shadow of what is to come; but the substance belongs to Christ.
Romans 14:5–6 (NAS) 5 One person regards one day above another, another regards every day alike. Each person must be fully convinced in his own mind. 6 He who observes the day, observes it for the Lord, and he who eats, does so for the Lord, for he gives thanks to God; and he who eats not, for the Lord he does not eat, and gives thanks to God.
item.content:encoded:
Colossians 2:16–17 (NAS)
16 Therefore no one is to act as your judge in regard to food or drink or in respect to a festival or a new moon or a Sabbath day— 17 things which are a mere shadow of what is to come; but the substance belongs to Christ.

Romans 14:5–6 (NAS)
5 One person regards one day above another, another regards every day alike. Each person must be fully convinced in his own mind. 6 He who observes the day, observes it for the Lord, and he who eats, does so for the Lord, for he gives thanks to God; and he who eats not, for the Lord he does not eat, and gives thanks to God.

item.title: By: Richard Taillefer
item.dc:creator: Richard Taillefer
item.description:
Hi Richard: Thanks for this explanation. The Lord used you to open my eyes to a strong argument from Isaiah 56. Isaiah 58 also has this same thought. Those who are set free from captivity, spiritual, shall call the Sabbath a delight...
Is there any validity to arguing that all this occurs after chapter 53 thereby also demonstrating that the Servant of the Lord brings a people out of spiritual captivity who will obey His law?
